Supporters often highlight the absence of immediate, large-scale health issues in the decades since GMO crops were introduced, interpreting this as evidence of safety.

Another common argument is that genetic modification is simply an extension of traditional selective breeding practices, just done more precisely. Advocates may suggest that because humans have altered crops for centuries, the modern tools used in genetic engineering are not inherently more dangerous.

There is also a tendency to place trust in the institutions and corporations that develop GMOs, assuming that economic and reputational stakes would prevent them from releasing unsafe products. Long-term, independent, and unbiased studies are still limited, and the complexity of the human body means that some health risks may not become apparent for years—or may only manifest in certain populations.
